{{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} In [[Irish mythology]] and genealogy, '''Aimend''' is the daughter of [[Óengus Bolg]], king of the [[Dáirine]] or [[Corcu Loígde]]. She marries [[Conall Corc]], founder of the [[Eóganachta]] dynasties, and through him is an ancestor of the "inner circle" septs of [[Eóganacht Chaisil]], [[Eóganacht Glendamnach]], and [[Eóganacht Áine]], who established the powerful kingship of [[Cashel, County Tipperary|Cashel]]. Details of the story imply she may have originally been a goddess (Byrne 2001: 166, 193).
==Etymology== This name appears to be derived from [[Proto-Celtic]] *''aidu-mandā''. The name literally means "burning stain," which may have been a byword for the notion of ‘sunburn’ (q.v. [http://www.wales.ac.uk/documents/external/cawcs/PCl-MoE.pdf] [http://www.wales.ac.uk/documents/external/cawcs/MoE-PCl.pdf] [https://web.archive.org/web/20060211181501/http://www.indo-european.nl/cgi-bin/query.cgi?root=leiden&basename=%5Cdata%5Cie%5Cceltic]). The [[Romano-British]] form of this [[Proto-Celtic]] name is likely to have been *''Aedumanda'' (q.v. [http://people.pwf.cam.ac.uk/dwew2/diachrony.pdf] [http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0022226702001706] [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article?tocId=74849&query=available%20name&ct=] [http://www.britannica.com/eb/article?tocId=74843&query=ogham&ct=]).
==References== * [[Francis John Byrne]], ''Irish Kings and High-Kings''. [[Four Courts Press]]. 2nd revised edition, 2001. * [[Thomas Charles-Edwards]], ''Early Christian Ireland''. Cambridge. 2000.
[[Category:Irish mythology]] [[Category:Irish goddesses]] [[Category:Solar goddesses]]
{{Europe-myth-stub}}

The '''Akassa tribe''' (Akasa, Akaha) of the [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] people lives along the Nun River estuary and the Atlantic coast of southern [[Bayelsa State]], [[Nigeria]]. Akassa settlements include: Opu-Akassa, Sangana, and Kamatoru.Alagoa, Ebiegberi Joe (2005). ''A History of the Niger Delta'', Port Harcourt: Onyoma Research Publications. {{ISBN|978-37314-5-9}}
==See also== *[[Akassa]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Akassa}} *[http://adf-akassa.org The Akassa Development Foundation] {{Nigeria-ethno-group-stub}} [[Category:Ijaw]] [[Category:Bayelsa State]]

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Apostolic Vicariate |name = Benghazi |latin = Vicariatus Apostolicus Berenicensis |local = النيابة الرسولية بنغازي |country = {{flag|Libya}} |metropolitan = Immediately subject to the Holy See |rite = [[Roman Rite]] |cathedral = |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 757,000 |population = 1,388,000 |population_as_of = 2014 |catholics = 6,000 |catholics_percent= 0.4 |bishop = [[Sede Vacante]] |bishop_title = Apostolic Vicar |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |apostolic_admin = George Bugeja }}
The '''Apostolic Vicariate of Benghazi''' ({{lang-la|Vicariatus Apostolicus Berenicensis}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[apostolic vicariate]] (missionary pre-[[diocese|diocesan]] jurisdiction) in [[Libya]].
It is exempt (i.e. directly subject to the [[Holy See]], not part of any ecclesiastical province), and has its [[cathedral]] see [[Benghazi Cathedral]] in the city of [[Benghazi]].
== History == * February 3, 1927: Established as '''Apostolic Vicariate of [[Cyrenaica]]''', on territory split from the [[Apostolic Vicariate of Libya]] * On June 22, 1939, renamed as Apostolic Vicariate of Benghazi and lost territory to established the [[Apostolic Vicariate of Derna]]
== Episcopal ordinaries == [[Image:Benghazi, Victory st..jpg|thumb|right|View of the [[Benghazi Cathedral]] about 1928]] :''So far, all [[Latin Rite]] ([[Roman Rite]]) missionary members of the [[Friars Minor]] (O.F.M.)
; Apostolic Vicars of Cirenaica (Roman Rite) * [[Bernardino Vitale Bigi]], O.F.M., [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Anthedon (Boeotia)|Anthedon]] (January 27, 1927 – April 19, 1930); also [[Apostolic Administrator]] of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Mogadishu|Mogadishu]] (Somalia) (1930.03 – 1930.04.19) * Candido Domenico Moro, O.F.M., Titular Bishop of [[Uzita (Tunisia)|Uzita]] (July 14, 1931 – June 22, 1939 ''see below'')
; Apostolic Vicars of Benghazi * [[Candido Domenico Moro]], O.F.M. (''see above'' June 22, 1939 – 1950) * [[Ernesto Aurelio Ghiglione]], O.F.M., Titular Bishop of [[Gauriana]] (July 5, 1951 – June 8, 1964) * [[Giustino Giulio Pastorino]], O.F.M., Titular Bishop of [[Babra, Gujarat|Babra]] (January 11, 1965 – March 10, 1997) * [[Sylvester Carmel Magro]], O.F.M., Titular Bishop of [[Saldæ]] (March 10, 1997 – February 14, 2016)
;Apostolic Administrators * George Bugeja, O.F.M., Titular Bishop of San Leone, Vicar Apostolic of Tripoli (February 14, 2016 – present)
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/beng1.htm GCatholic.org, with incumbent biography links] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dbngh.html Catholic Hierarchy]
{{coord missing|Libya}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} [[File:Escorte Royale à Cheval.JPG|right|thumb|The Belgian Royal Escort during [[Belgian National Day]] 2018]] The '''Belgian Royal Escort''' ({{lang-nl|Koninklijk escorte te paard}}, {{lang-fr|Escorte royale à cheval}}) is a horse- and motorcycle-mounted unit that accompanies the [[Belgian monarchy|Belgian monarch]] on ceremonial occasions. It also provides escorts for foreign visiting heads of state and ambassadors presenting their credentials at the Royal Palace in Brussels.
==Composition== The Royal Escort is not a full-time unit but is brought together on occasions of major ceremony as noted above. It is provided by units of the [[Policing in Belgium#Federal Police|Federal Police]]. Prior to the merger of the [[Belgian Gendarmerie|Gendarmerie]] and Police, the unit was provided by the Gendarmerie. There are two Royal Escorts: the mounted escort and the motorcycle escort.
==History== The Belgian monarchs have been accompanied by a mounted escort on state occasions since Belgium's [[Belgian Revolution|independence]] in 1830. Until 1914 these were provided by detachments drawn from either the ''Marie-Henriette'' squadron of the [[Garde Civique|Civic Guard]] of Brussels or from the [[Guides Regiment|Guides Regiments]] of the regular cavalry of the Belgian Army, based in Brussels. After World War I the disbandment of the Civic Guard led to a suggestion that a separate mounted ceremonial unit be established but the proposal was left in abeyance until the Belgian cavalry was mechanized in 1938. Accordingly in that year a permanent Royal Escort was created as part of the Gendarmerie. The full dress uniform of [[bearskin]], black tunic and white breeches then adopted, and still worn, had been that of the mounted gendarmerie prior to 1914.
==Modern escorts== The cavalry unit of the General Reserve of the Federal Police is responsible for providing the escort. The 132 riders of the Royal Escort all have [[Belgian (horse)|Belgian mounts]].
On January 5, 1960, [[Baudouin I of Belgium|King Baudouin]] granted the Gendarmerie the privilege of creating a motorised unit tasked with escorting him and important guests. Nowadays, the motorcycle escort is provided by the Provincial Traffic Unit Brabant of the Federal Police's road traffic police.
==See also== * [[Federal Police (Belgium)]] * [[Policing in Belgium]]
[[Category:Federal law enforcement agencies of Belgium|Royal]] [[Category:Belgian monarchy]] [[Category:Honour guards]]
{{Belgium-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Bysen''' ({{IPA-sv|byːsɛn}}) is a legendary [[gnome]]-like creature that haunts the woods of the island of [[Gotland]], [[Sweden]]. He carries an axe. He is said to have committed a crime, and condemned to walk the Earth forever. He attracts people, making them get lost. Often he meddles with woodsmen, delays their transports, and tips loads of timber over. He often interferes with men in other ways and is accused of all sorts of mischief. The Bys often appears as a stump or an insignificant, little, grey man. Sometimes he wears a red, woven cap and an axe, because one of his tasks is to cut down Gotland's forest. This goes slowly however and sometimes only one tree per century is felled. It's said the Bys is a humanoid who has done some crime within his lifetime, and is therefore sentenced to wander the earth forever. The Bys is also the ward of the forest and nature.
Similar to a [[Deildegast]], some sources say that the Bysar are deceased people who have cheated other men out of their land by moving the markers that separated two holdings. As punishment they get no peace in the grave, and are doomed to go along the faulty border, moving the sticks which stand on the wrong land. It's said that as they walk you can hear them mumble, "This is right, this is wrong" while moving the markers. If a human follows Bysen and moves the wrongly placed sticks to the right places then Bysen will gain peace. On the Swedish mainland the counterpart to Bysen is called ''skälvrängare'' or ''osaliga lantmätare'' (approximately: ''unholy landsurveyor'').
If Bysen catches sight of you where you are in the forest he will enchant your vision so that you can not find him again. What returns one's vision to normal is to turn a garment crooked.
==Etymology and Spelling== The word ''bys'' most likely comes from the Swedish word ''bus'', which means mischief or prank.
Its declinations in Swedish with English translations: {| class="wikitable" ! singular form with indefinite article!! plural form !! definite form with article !! definite plural form |- |en bys||bysar||bysen||bysarna |- |''a bys''||''bysar''||''bysen''||''the bysar'' |}
[[Category:Gotland]] [[Category:Scandinavian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Scandinavian folklore]]
{{Europe-myth-stub}}

[[File:Yanjingshe album.jpg|240px|thumb|The Chinese release of the first self-named album ''Yanjingshe'']] '''Cobra''' (眼镜蛇乐队 ''Yanjingshe yuedui'') was an all-female rock band from [[Beijing]], [[People's Republic of China|China]]. The band formed in 1989, becoming the first all-female rock band in mainland China.<ref>Ian Peddie Popular Music and Human Rights: World music 2011 - Page 133 "However, by the time the first rock bands appeared in Beijing, Mao had died (1976) and John Lennon had been shot ... and Panther (Hei Bao) already existed, and new bands like Breathing (Huxi), the all-female band Cobra (Yanjing she) ..."</ref> With only one album out, they disbanded in the late 1990s. Their style was a gloomy, bluesy type of [[hard rock]] with slight touches of [[New wave music|new wave]] and [[alternative metal]]. Cobra was very popular in the beginning of their career.
Group members include Yang Ying, Yu Jin, Wang Xiaofang, and Xiao Nan. They have played at [[CBGB]] in [[New York City]].
==Discography== *1994 - First released as ''Hypocrisy'' (Germany 1994, USA 1996) republished as ''Yanjingshe'' (China 1996)<ref>Chime: Newsletter of the European Foundation for Chinese Music ... 1999- Issues 12-13 - Page 153 Cobra recorded their first solo-CD 'Hypocrisy' after a successful tour through Germany in 1993. It was published by Network Medien GmbH'. Frankfurt. 1994. in cooperation with the Hans der Kulturen tier Welt. Berlin Later, the record was also published in China under the title Yanjing she (Cobra), by the China Record Corporation. Guangzhou. 1996 In the course of time, the music market</ref> *2000 - ''Cobra - Yangjingshe II '' (China)
==References== {{reflist}} *Wong, Cynthia P. (2005). "Lost Lambs": Rock, Gender, Authenticity, and A Generational Response to Modernity in the People's Republic of China." Ph.D. dissertation. New York, New York: Columbia University, 2005.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050521082042/http://www.niubi.com/cobra/ Cobra fansite] *[http://www.beijingscene.com/v07i011/cdscene.html Review of Cobra II] *[http://www.yangying-music.com/ Yang Ying official site] *[http://www.wang-xiaofang.com/ Wang Xiaofang's site]
==See also== *[[Chinese rock]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cobra}} [[Category:All-female bands]] [[Category:Chinese rock music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups from Beijing]]
{{china-band-stub}}

{{Infobox anthem |title = El Gran Carlemany |english_title = The Great Charlemagne |image = Bandera de Andorra.jpg |prefix = National |country = {{AND}} |composer = Enric Marfany Bons |author = [[Juan Benlloch i Vivó]] |adopted = September 8, 1921 |sound = El Gran Carlemany.ogg |sound_title = }} '''"El Gran Carlemany"''' ({{IPA-ca|əl ˈɣɾaŋ kəɾləˈmaɲ}}; "The Great Charlemagne") is the [[national anthem]] of the [[Andorra|Principality of Andorra]]. Enric Marfany Bons composed the music, while the lyrics were authored by [[Joan Benlloch i Vivó]], written in a first-person narrative. It was adopted as the national anthem on September 8, 1921, which is also the national day of Andorra. The lyrics make reference to several key aspects of [[Culture of Andorra|Andorran culture]] and [[History of Andorra|history]], such as the heritage of the [[Carolingian Empire]]. ==Lyrics== {|class="wikitable" cellpadding="15" rules="cols" !'''''El Gran Carlemany''
([[Catalan language|Catalan]])'''{{cite web|title=Andorra – ''El Gran Carlemany''|url=http://www.nationalanthems.me/andorra-el-gran-carlemany/|date=|accessdate=May 19, 2014|work=|publisher=NationalAnthems.me}}!!'''El Gran Carlomagno
([[Spanish language|Spanish]] translation)'''!!'''El Gran Carlemany
([[French language|French]] translation)'''!!'''The Great Charlemagne
(English translation)'''{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O4MNjT4QS0EC&pg=PA24|title=Andorra|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|date=September 1, 2008|last=Augustin|first=Byron|page=24}} |- |colspan="4" bgcolor="#002B7F"|{{centre|'''First verse'''}} |- |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| ''El gran Carlemany, mon pare,'' ''dels alarbs em deslliurà,'' ''I del cel vida em donà,'' ''de Meritxell, la gran Mare.'' |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| El gran Carlomagno, mi padre, me liberó de los árabes, Y del cielo vida me dio, de Meritxell, la gran Madre, |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Le Grand Charlemagne mon père nous délivra des arabes et du ciel me donna la vie, de Meritxell la grande Mère. |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| The great [[Charlemagne]], my father, from the [[Saracen|Saracens]] liberated me And from heaven he gave me life, of [[Our Lady of Meritxell|Meritxell]], the great Mother. |- |colspan="4" bgcolor="#FCD116"|{{centre|'''Second verse'''}} |- |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| ''Princesa nasquí i Pubilla'' ''entre dues nacions, neutral;'' ''sols resto l'única filla,'' ''de l'imperi Carlemany.'' |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Princesa nací y heredera, entre dos naciones, neutral Soy la única hija que queda del Imperio Carolingio. |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Je suis née Princesse héritière, neutre entre deux nations, Je reste la seule fille de l'empereur Charlemagne. |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Princess, born Heiress Into two nations, in neutrality; I am the only remaining daughter, of the [[Carolingian Empire|Carolingian empire]]. |- |colspan="4" bgcolor="#CE1126"|{{centre|'''Third verse'''}} |- |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| ''Creient i lliure onze segles, ''creient i lliure vull ser.'' ''Siguin els furs mos tutors'' ''i mos Prínceps defensors!'' ''I mos Prínceps defensors!'' |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Creyente y libre once siglos; creyente y libre quiero ser. ¡Sean los fueros mis tutores y mis Príncipes defensores! ¡Y mis Príncipes defensores! |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Croyante et libre onze siècles, croyante et libre je veux demeurer Que les Fueros soient mes tuteurs et mes Princes mes défenseurs! Et mes Princes mes défenseurs! |style="font-family: Georgia, Palatino, Palatino Linotype, Times, Times New Roman, serif"| Faithful and free for eleven centuries, Faithful and free I will be. The laws of the land be my tutors, and my Princes{{#tag:ref|Augustin's ''Andorra'' book reference incorrectly translates "Prínceps" as "princess". It should instead be "princes", alluding to the [[Co-Princes of Andorra]].|group=upper-alpha}} defenders! And my Princes defenders! |} ==History== "El Gran Carlemany" was composed by Enric Marfany Bons (1871–1942),{{cite book|author=Xavier Maugendre|title=L'Europe des hymnes dans leur contexte historique et musical|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tAtItyiK9ywC&pg=PA145|year=1996|publisher=Editions Mardaga|isbn=978-2-87009-632-1|page=145}} who was a priest.Augustin (2008), p. 99. The lyrics to the song were penned by [[Juan Benlloch i Vivó]] (1864–1926), who served as the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Urgell|Bishop of Urgell]] from 1906 to 1919. This position also made him an ''ex officio'' [[Co-Princes of Andorra|Co–Prince of Andorra]].{{cite news|title=The Not-so-Rough Guide to Andorra – The land that Europe forgot|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:TND1&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=1338548EB32BEE08&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=105B9A93AF33E3E3|date=September 2, 2006|accessdate=May 7, 2014|first=John|last=Lichfield|pages=26–27|newspaper=The Independent|location=London}} {{subscription required}} The song was officially designated as the country's national anthem on September 8, 1921,{{cite web|title=Andorra|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/an.html|date=|accessdate=May 7, 2014|work=The World Factbook|publisher=CIA}}{{cite web|title=Country's Profile – Andorra|url=http://www.sochi2014.com/en/team-andorra-profile|work=Sochi2014.com|publisher=Sochi 2014 Olympics|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140406222721/http://www.sochi2014.com/en/team-andorra-profile|archivedate=April 6, 2014|accessdate=May 7, 2014}} when it was sung at the country's cathedral for the first time.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i00KAQAAIAAJ&q=Our+Lady+of+Meritxell+el+gran+carlemany|title=Principat D'Andorra, 1278–1978: È Centenari de la Signatura Dels Pareatges – Recull Oficial D'informació|publisher=Casa de la Vall|year=1978}} The day it was adopted – September 8 – is the [[National Day]] of Andorra. This coincides with the feast day of [[Our Lady of Meritxell]], the country's patron saint who is mentioned in the lyrics. ==Context of lyrics== The lyrics of "El Gran Carlemany" give a short account of Andorra's history "in a [[first-person narrative]]". It recounts the traditional Andorran [[legend]] that [[Charlemagne]] reconquered the region from the [[Moors]] between 788{{cite journal|last=Geyer|first=Helen|date=November 2013|title=Sprachpolitik und-praxis in Andorra|journal=Interlinguistische Informationen|volume=20|pages=68|publisher=Diputació de Girona|accessdate=May 8, 2014|issn=1432-3567|url=http://www.interlinguistik-gil.de/wb/media/beihefte/20/beiheft20.pdf#page=68|language=de}} and 790, after the Catalan people had guided his army through the rugged valleys, which Charlemagne compensated with granting Andorra its independence,{{cite book|title=Principat D'Andorra, 1278–1978: È Centenari de la Signatura Dels Pareatges : Recull Oficial D'informació|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i00KAQAAIAAJ|date=1978|publisher=Casa de la Vall}} and its first borders were delineated that same year. It formed part of the ''[[Marca Hispanica]]'', a [[buffer zone]] formed by Charlemagne in order to protect his state (the [[Carolingian Empire]]).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5qlXatHRJtMC&pg=PA8|title=Nation Shapes: The Story Behind the World's Borders|publisher=ABC–CLIO|date=April 23, 2013|last=Shelley|first=Fred M.|page=8}} According to legend, he was responsible for restructuring the country, reintroducing [[Christianity]] to its people and overseeing the construction of monasteries. Because of these accomplishments, he was given "a mythical aura" and is regarded as the founder of Andorra.{{cite journal|last=Pineda|first=Enric Bassegoda|year=2010|title=Carlemany No Va Conquerir Girona|journal=Revista de Girona|volume=261|pages=39|publisher=Diputació de Girona|accessdate=May 8, 2014|url=http://www.raco.cat/index.php/RevistaGirona/article/view/205896/274434|language=ca}} The hymn begins with "El gran Carlemany mon pare" ("Great Charlemagne my father"),{{cite book|author1=Gale Group|author2=Moshe Y. Sachs|title=Worldmark Encyclopedia of the Nations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yO8XAQAAMAAJ|year=1984|publisher=Gale Group|page=9}} and memorializes this view and celebrates the country's status as "the only remaining daughter of the Carolingian empire,"{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rmSYoANVCDkC&pg=PT41|title=Iberian Worlds|publisher=Routledge|date=September 28, 2010|last=McDonogh|first=Gary}} since it is the only remnant of the Marca Hispanica. ==Notes== {{reflist|group=upper-alpha}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.d.umn.edu/cla/faculty/troufs/midis/andorraX.mp3 Recording by the New Japan Philharmonic (former linked source stale.)] {{National Anthems of Europe}} {{Portal bar|Andorra|Music}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gran Carlemany, El}} [[Category:European anthems]] [[Category:National symbols of Andorra]] [[Category:Andorran songs]] [[Category:20th-century establishments in Andorra]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Charlemagne]] [[Category:1921 songs]] [[Category:National anthems]] [[Category:Songs about royalty]] [[Category:Compositions in G major]] {{Andorra-stub}}

{{expand Finnish|Entten tentten teelikamentten|date=February 2018}} '''Entten tentten teelikamentten''' is an old [[Finland|Finnish]] [[nursery rhyme]]. ''Entten tentten teelikamentten
''hissun kissun vaapula vissun
''eelin keelin klot
''viipula vaapula vot
''Eskon saun piun paun.'' ''Nyt sää lähdet tästä pelistä pois,
''Puh pah pelistä pois!''{{Cite web|url = http://www.kotikielenseura.fi/virittaja/hakemistot/jutut/2002_85.pdf|title = Ikola, Osmo: ''Entten tentten teelikamentten. Erään lastenlorun arvoitus'' (pdf)|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}'' == See also == * [[Nursery rhyme]] * [[Akka bakka bonka rakka]] * [[Eeny, meeny, miny, moe]] * [[En Den Dino]] * [[Ip dip]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Ikola, Osmo: ''Entten tentten teelikamentten. Erään lastenlorun arvoitus''. Virittäjä 1/2002. Kotikielen Seura. Viitattu 11.12.2011 ([http://www.kotikielenseura.fi/virittaja/hakemistot/jutut/2002_85.pdf pdf at kotikielenseura.fi]) * ''The counting-out rhymes of children: their antiquity, origin, and wide distribution; a study in folk-lore'', Henry Carrington Bolton, 1888 ([https://archive.org/details/countingoutrhyme00bolt online version at archive.org]) * ''More Counting-out Rhymes'', H. Carrington Bolton in ''The Journal of American Folklore'' Vol. 10, No. 39 (Oct. - Dec., 1897), pp. 313–321. Published by: American Folklore Society DOI: 10.2307/533282 Stable URL: ([https://www.jstor.org/stable/533282 online version at JStor]) * Gregor, Walter, 1891: ''Counting-out rhymes of children ([https://archive.org/details/cu31924029909649 online version at archive.org] * SKVR XII1 2837. ''Alatornio''. PLK. A 2212. -15 ([https://skvr.fi/ online version at SKVR.fi]) [[Category:Finnish-language literature]] [[Category:Nursery rhymes]] {{finland-stub}} {{poem-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox Military Award |name=Flood Disaster Medal |image=Watersnoodmedaille.jpg |image_size=100px |caption= The bronze medal |awarded_by=[[Image:Flag of the Netherlands.svg|18px]] [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] |type= [[Civil decoration]],
with degrees silver and bronze |eligibility= |for= |status= Not currently awarded |description= |clasps= |established=27 March 1855 |first_award= |last_award= |total= |posthumous= |recipients= |individual= |higher=[[Museum Medal]] |lower= [[Medal of the Red Cross (Netherlands)|Medal of the Red Cross]] |image2=[[Image:Baton Watersnoodmedaille in Brons.jpg|85px|]] |caption2=The ribbon bar of a bronze medal }} The '''Decoration for acknowledgement of excellent deeds performed during a flood disaster''' ({{lang-nl|Onderscheidingsteken ter erkenning van uitstekende daden bij watersnood verricht}}), usually called '''Flood disaster Medal''' ({{lang-nl|Watersnoodmedaille}}), was created by royal decree on 27 March 1855 by [[King William III of the Netherlands]]. The medal is intended for those civilians who have shown zeal, courage, leadership, and self-sacrifice during the event of a flood disaster [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of the Netherlands]] [[Category:1855 establishments in the Netherlands]] {{odm-stub}} {{Netherlands-stub}}

{{Infobox Ethnic group |group= Greek Brazilians
''Greco-brasileiros {{·}} Ελληνοβραζιλιάνοι'' | image = |population='''50,000 Greek Brazilians'''[http://www.memorialdoimigrante.org.br/historico/index.htm Greeks in Brazil] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323095757/http://www.memorialdoimigrante.org.br/historico/index.htm |date=2009-03-23 }} |popplace=[[Brazil]]: Mainly [[Southeastern Brazil]] |langs= Predominantly [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] |rels=[[Roman Catholic]], [[Greek Orthodox]] |related= Other [[White Brazilian]], [[Greek people]] }} '''Greek Brazilians''' ({{lang-el|Ελληνοβραζιλιάνοι|Hellenovrazilianoi}}, {{lang-pt|Greco-brasileiros}}) are [[Brazil]]ian residents who are either fully or partially of Greek descent. They are located throughout Brazil with numbers of about 50,000 people and with 20,000 Greeks living in [[São Paulo]] alone. ==Notable Greek Brazilians== * [[João Pandiá Calogeras]], Brazilian Minister of War, of Greek origin, during WWI * [[Bruna Griphao]] - television actress * [[Cleo Rocos]] - comedy actress, presenter and business woman * [[Constantine Andreou]] - painter and sculptor * [[Constantino Tsallis]] - physicist * [[Miguel Nicolelis]] - neuroscientist * [[Pavlos Papaioannou]] - former football player * [[Ronald Golias]] - comedian * [[Silvio Santos]] - TV host and entrepreneur * [[Vitor Belfort]] - Mixed Martial Artist * [[Leonardo Koutris]] - footballer ==See also== {{Portal|Brazil|Greece}} * [[Immigration to Brazil]] * [[White Brazilians]] * [[Greek people]] * [[Greek diaspora]] * [[Brazil–Greece relations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060713190921/http://www.mfa.gr/www.mfa.gr/en-US/Policy/Geographic+Regions/Latin+America+-+Caribbean/Bilateral+Relations/Brazil/ Bilateral relations between Greece and Brazil] {{Ancestry and ethnicity in Brazil}} {{Brazil topics}} {{Greek diaspora}} [[Category:Brazilian people of Greek descent| ]] [[Category:European Brazilian]] [[Category:Greek minorities|Brazil]] {{Brazil-ethno-group-stub}} {{Greece-stub}}

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Kievan Past | image = | caption = | type = Monthly | format = [[Broadsheet]] | foundation = 1 February 1882 | ceased publication = 1907 | price = | owners = | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = [[Feofan Lebedintsev]] (founder) | assoceditor = | maneditor = | staff = | language = Russian, Ukrainian | political = Historically ethographic and literal chronicles | circulation = [[Kiev]] city | headquarters = Kiev | sister newspapers = | oclc = | ISSN = | website = }} [[File:Kievan Past Journal, celebration of 15-years-old anniversary, 1898.png|thumb|400px|Celebration of the Kievskaya starina 15th anniversary, 1898; sitting [[Pavlo Zhytetsky|Zhytetsky]], Lazarevskyi, [[Veniamin Tarnovskyi|Tarnovskyi]], [[Mykhailo Chalyi|Chalyi]], [[Mykola Shuhurov|Shuhurov]], [[Volodymyr Antonovych|Antonovych]], [[Kostyantyn Mykhalchuk|Mykhalchuk]], [[Andriy Storozhenko|A.Storozhenko]], [[Volodymyr Shcherbyna|Shcherbyna]]; standing Kivlytskyi, [[Mykola Vasylenko|Vasylenko]], [[Andronik Stepovych|Stepovych]], [[Nykandr Molchanovskyi|Molchanovskyi]], [[Orest Levytskyi|Levytskyi]], [[Mykola Storozhenko (historian)|M.Storozhenko]], [[Venedikt Miakotin|Miakotin]]]] [[File:Ukraina (magazine Kyiv 1907).png|thumb|Ukrayina magazine, 1907]] '''''Kievskaya starina''''' ({{lang-ru|Киевская старина}}, literally means ''Kievan Past'') was a historically ethographic and literal chronicle (monthly magazine). It was published in [[Kiev]] in [[Russian language]] and [[Ukrainian language]] during 1882-1907.
In the last year of its existence when censorship on [[Ukrainian language]] was dropped, the periodical was renamed '''''Ukraine''''' and was published in Ukrainian. The monthly chronicle played a major role in development of [[Ukrainian culture]] under the conditions of the [[Russian Empire]]. Together with the periodical worked such people as [[Volodymyr Antonovych]], [[Dmytro Bahaliy]], [[Mykola Kostomarov]], [[Pavlo Zhytetskyi]], [[Orest Levytskyi]], [[Oleksandr Yefymenko]], [[Oleksandr Lazarevskyi]] etc.
Main sponsor of the magazine was [[Hryhoriy Galagan]].
Along with the magazine, in 1899 [[Mykola Biliashivsky]] started to publish his "Arkheologicheskaya letopis Yuzhnoi Rossii" (Archaeological chronicle of the Southern Russia) at first as an addition, but in 1901-1905 as a separate magazine.
After Kievaskaya starina ceased to be published, in 1907 Naumenko continued to publish monthly magazine under name ''Ukrayina'' for year.
In the late Soviet period attempts were made to revive the magazine in 1970s, but only since 1992 [[Petro Tolochko]] managed to establish a magazine of the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]], ''Kyivska starovyna'' which is published in [[Ukrainian language]].
==Chief editors== * 1882-1887 [[Feofan Lebedintsev]] * 1887-1889 [[Oleksandr Lashkevych]] * 1890-1896 [[Yevhen Kivlytskyi]] * 1893-1906 [[Volodymyr Pavlovych Naumenko]]
<gallery> File:Лобода.png|Lebedintsev File:Oleksandr Laškevyč.png|Lashkevych File:Naumenko-226x300.jpg|Naumenko </gallery>
==References== * [http://journlib.univ.kiev.ua/index.php?act=article&article=307 A. Volobuewa. Journal «Киевская старина» in defense of Ukrainian language]
==External links== * [http://iht.univ.kiev.ua/library/kievskaya-starina/all-articles Kievskaya starina] digitized at the Institute of High Technologies ([[Kiev University]]) * [http://litopys.org.ua/rizne/star21.htm An episode at the Taras Shevcheko's grave] (notes of painter Chestakhovsky). Kievskaya starina article at [[Izbornik]]. 1896.

{{Infobox station | name = Lilleküla | type = Train station | style = | image = Tallinn-Lilleküla jaam-2010-04-11.JPG | image_size = | image_caption = Lilleküla station in 2010 with old platforms. | address = | country = Estonia | coordinates = {{coord|59|25|32|N|24|43|39|E|type:railwaystation_region:EE|display=inline,title}} | line = [[Elron (rail transit)|Elron]] [[commuter rail]] | other = | structure = at-grade | platform = 2 | depth = | levels = | tracks = 2 | parking = | bicycle = | baggage_check = | opened = 1928 | closed = | rebuilt = | electrified = [[List of current systems for electric rail traction#3 kV DC|3 kV DC]] [[Overhead lines|OHLE]] | ADA = | code = | owned = | operator = | zone = | smartcardname = | smartcardstatus = | former = | passengers = | pass_year = | pass_percent = | pass_system = | mpassengers = | services = | map_locator = }} '''Lilleküla railway station''' ({{lang-et|Lilleküla raudteepeatus}}) is a railway station in [[Tallinn]], the capital of [[Estonia]]. It is the second stop on [[Elron (rail transit)|Elron]]'s western route after the terminus Tallinn's main railway station [[Balti jaam]]. It is located about 2 km south of [[Balti jaam]] between the subdistricts [[Lilleküla]] and [[Uus Maailm]]. The station is served by all commuter trains heading to [[Keila]], [[Paldiski]], [[Riisipere]] and [[Kloogaranna]]. It consists of two 130 metre platforms. Close to Lilleküla station there is the Estonian national football home ground [[A. Le Coq Arena]] and one of the biggest and most popular shopping centres in Tallinn [[Kristiine Keskus]]. Although the Tallinn–[[Paldiski]] railway existed already in 1870, a station on the site was opened in 1928. The line from Tallinn to back then a nearby town [[Nõmme]] (as far as [[Pääsküla]]) was electrified already in 1924. At first the station bore the name "Ameerika". There was also a little wooden station building which was demolished in 1998.{{cite web|last=Tõllasepp|first=Jaan|title=Tallinna ja Harjumaa elektriraudtee: Lilleküla|url=http://www.hot.ee/transportation/est/elektrirong/lillekyla.html|accessdate=30 June 2012|language=Estonian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927083257/http://www.hot.ee/transportation/est/elektrirong/lillekyla.html|archivedate=27 September 2013|df=}} In 2012 the old platforms were replaced with new lower ones and a pedestrian tunnel was built.{{cite news|last=Gnadenteich|first=Uwe|title=Lilleküla jalakäijate tunnel on tänasest avatud|url=http://www.tallinnapostimees.ee/1082776/lillekula-jalakaijate-tunnel-on-tanasest-avatud|accessdate=26 December 2012|newspaper=[[Postimees|Tallinna Postimees]]|date=2012-12-21|language=Estonian}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{commons category|Lilleküla railway station}} {{Estonia-train-station | previous=[[Balti jaam]]
(Tallinn) | header=[[Elron (rail transit)|Elron]] Westward lines | station=Lilleküla | next=[[Tondi railway station|Tondi]]}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lillekula railway station}} [[Category:Railway stations in Estonia]] [[Category:Transport in Tallinn]] [[Category:Railway stations opened in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Estonia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tallinn]] {{Estonia-struct-stub}} {{Europe-railstation-stub}} {{Estonia-transport-stub}}

News |date=2012-02-23 |accessdate=2014-06-11}} |1991– |- ||Spain |7 ft 3 in (221 cm) |[[Roberto Dueñas|Roberto Dueñas Hernández]] |Tallest Spanish basketball player ever (now retired). revision.comment: add eponymous category if it already exists: [[Category:Malta–Slovakia relations]]
revision.text:
{{bilateral|Malta-Slovakia|Malta|Slovakia}}
'''Malta–Slovakia relations''' are foreign relations between [[Malta]] and the [[Slovakia]]. Malta is represented in Slovakia through a non resident ambassador based in [[Valletta]] (in the Foreign Ministry). Slovakia is represented in Malta through its embassy in [[Rome]] ([[Italy]]) and an honorary consulate in [[Valletta]]. Both countries are full members of the [[European Union]] and both are fully within the [[Eurozone]].
==History== Malta backed the Slovak Republic to join the eurozone.<ref>{{cite news| publisher=[[The Malta Independent]] | title=Malta and Slovakia to strengthen bilateral political and economic relations | url=http://www.independent.com.mt/news.asp?newsitemid=95118 | date=December 8, 2009 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref> In 2000, Maltese Prime Minister [[Edward Fenech Adami]] also told Slovak President [[Rudolf Schuster]] in [[Bratislava]] that Malta supported Slovakia in its efforts to join [[NATO]] and the European Union.<ref>{{cite news| publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] | title=Slovak president, Maltese premier discuss cooperation, EU, NATO bid | url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=BBAB&d_place=BBAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F97DAE286AF681B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | date=2000-05-17 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref> Since both countries' entries to the [[European Union]], officials have also made efforts to strengthen relations based on tourism.<ref>{{cite web | publisher=[[The Malta Independent]] | title=Improving ties with Slovakia | url=http://www.independent.com.mt/news.asp?newsitemid=23146 | date= | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref>
== Bilateral agreements == As of 2008, Slovakia and Malta had six bilateral agreements spelling out cooperation in the avoidance of double taxation, air services, health care, combating crime, visa abolition, and investment.<ref>{{cite web | title=Malta-Slovakia discuss cooperation | url=http://f1plus.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081010/local/malta-slovakia-discuss-cooperation | publisher=[[Times of Malta]] | date=2008-10-10 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref>
In September 2009, Malta and Slovakia signed a memorandum of understanding setting the framework within which authorities from the two countries will identify, screen and facilitate the process of adoption of Slovak children by couples in Malta.<ref>{{cite web | title=Agreement on adoptions signed | url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20090925/local/agreement-on-adoptions-signed | publisher=[[Times of Malta]] | date=2009-09-25 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref>
== Official visits == In 2001 Slovak prime minister [[Mikuláš Dzurinda]] visited Malta at the invitation of Maltese premier [[Edward Fenech Adami]], and negotiated the integration of both countries into the European Union and the economic cooperation between Malta and Slovakia.<ref>{{cite web | title=Informácia o priebehu a výsledkoch oficiálnej návštevy predsedu vlády SR Mikuláša Dzurindu na Malte v dňoch 18. - 19. júna 2001 | url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:eP-TE1k3zasJ:www.rokovania.sk/appl/material.nsf/0/93E6675B3BA1E98BC1256A860033ADC2/%24FILE/material.rtf+Malta+Slovensko+vz%C5%A5ahy&cd=13&hl=cs&ct=clnk&client=opera | work= | publisher=Úrad vlády Slovenskej republiky (Slovak Government) | date= | accessdate=2009-05-11|language=sk}}</ref> Also in 2001, President of Malta [[Guido de Marco]] made a two-day official visit to Slovakia and met with Slovak President Rudolf Schuster. They agreed to widen cooperation in food and wood processing industries along with tourism.<ref>{{cite web |title=Slovak, Maltese presidents agree on need to encourage mutual trade | publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] | url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=BBAB&d_place=BBAB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F97A00751942154&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | date=2001-03-27 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref> In 2008 Slovak agency SARIA signed with [[Malta Enterprise]] a treaty of reciprocal assistance related to third world countries.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web | title=Príhovor podpredsedu vlády SR počas spoločenského podniku pri príležitosti štátneho sviatku SR a 40. výročia nadviazania diplomatických stykov medzi SR a Maltou vo Vallette. | url=http://www.vlada.gov.sk/14021/prihovor-podpredsedu-vlady-sr-pocas-spolocenskeho-podniku-pri-prilezitosti-statneho-sviatku-sr-a-40-vyrocia-nadviazania-diplomatickych-stykov-medzi-sr-a-maltou-vo-vallette.php | work= | publisher=Úrad vlády SR (Slovak Government) | date= |accessdate=2009-05-11|language=sk}}</ref> Slovak Prime Minister [[Robert Fico]] visited Maltese capital [[Valletta]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news| title=Fico na Malte rokuje s premiérom o skúsenostiach s eurom a obchode | url=http://hnonline.sk/slovensko/c1-22749070-fico-na-malte-rokuje-s-premierom-o-skusenostiach-s-eurom-a-obchode | work= | publisher=Hospodárske noviny online | date= | accessdate=2009-05-11|language=sk}}</ref>
Slovak Deputy Prime Minister [[Dusan Caplovic]] visited Malta in October 2008 and had a meeting with Foreign Minister [[Tonio Borg]]. Dr. Borg described Maltese/Slovak relations as excellent. The Foreign Ministers discussed EU matters, notably the [[Lisbon Treaty]], bilateral relations, illegal immigration, climate change and energy security issues.<ref>{{cite news| title=Malta-Slovakia discuss cooperation | url=http://f1plus.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20081010/local/malta-slovakia-discuss-cooperation | publisher=[[Times of Malta]] | date=2008-10-10 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref>
Dr. Borg and the Foreign Affairs Minister of the Slovak Republic, [[Miroslav Lajcak]], met in October 2009. Dr. Borg said that Slovakia is committed to help Malta to share its burden on illegal immigration and the Slovak Government announced that it will be taking a number of illegal immigrants from Malta.<ref>{{cite web | title=Slovakia will also be taking illegal immigrants from Malta |url=http://www.foreign.gov.mt/default.aspx?MDIS=21&NWID=630 | publisher=[[Malta|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Malta]] | date=2009-10-16 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | publisher=[[The Malta Independent]] | title=Slovakia to take | url=http://www.independent.com.mt/searchresult.asp?PageNo=6 |date= | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Slovakia may help Malta in resettlement of migrants | url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20090721/local/slovakkia-may-help-malta-in-resettlement-of-migrants |publisher=[[Times of Malta]] | date=2009-07-21 | accessdate=2009-12-04}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Foreign relations of Malta]] * [[Foreign relations of Slovakia]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.foreign.gov.mt/default.aspx?MDIS=144&MLEV=6 Maltese representations in Slovakia] * [http://www.foreign.gov.mt/default.aspx?MDIS=288&MLEV=8 Slovakian representations in Malta] * [http://www.slovakiamalta.com/ Slovakian honorary consulate in Valletta]
{{Foreign relations of Malta}} {{Foreign relations of Slovakia}}

revision.text:
The '''Moyzes Quartet''' is a [[Slovakia]]n [[string quartet]]. It was founded in 1975, and consists of Stanislav Mucha (first violin), Fratinšek Török (second violin), Alexander Lakatoš (viola) and Ján Slávik (cello).
The members of the quartet studied first at the [[Bratislava Academy of Music and Performing Arts]], then at the [[Hochschule fur Musik und darstellende Kunst]] in Vienna. The quartet has made over 30 recordings, including works by [[Shostakovich]], [[Antonín Dvořák|Dvořák]], [[Smetana]], and [[Slovak composer]]s such as [[Jan Levoslav Bella]], [[Alexander Moyzes]] and [[Eugen Suchon]].
[[Category:Slovak musical groups]] [[Category:String quartets]]
{{Europe-band-stub}}

{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Slovakia}} "Nekonečná pieseň" | image = | caption = | year = 1994 | country = Slovakia | artist = [[Maťo Ďurinda|Martin Ďurinda]],
Juraj Topor,
Jozef Dubán,
Juraj Černý | as = [[Tublatanka]] | with = | language = Slovak | languages = | composer = [[Maťo Ďurinda|Martin Ďurinda]] | lyricist = Martin Sarvaš | conductor = Vladimir Valović | place = 19th | points = 15 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1994sk from Diggiloo Thrush] | next = Kým nás máš | next_link = Kým nás máš | next_year = 1996 }} '''"Nekonečná pieseň"''' (Neverending song) was the [[Slovakia|Slovak]] entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1994]]. The first Slovak entry, it was sung by [[rock band]] [[Tublatanka]] in the [[Slovak language]]. The song was performed fifteenth on the night, following [[Germany]]'s [[Mekado]] with "[[Wir geben 'ne Party]]" and preceding [[Lithuania]]'s [[Ovidijus Vyšniauskas]] with "[[Lopšinė mylimai]]". At the close of voting, it had received 15 points, placing nineteenth in a field of twenty five. It was succeeded as Slovak representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996|1996 contest]] by [[Marcel Palonder]] with "[[Kým nás máš]]". {{Slovakia in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1994}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nekonecna piesen}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Slovakia]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1994]] [[Category:1994 songs]] {{Slovakia-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Hollow Needle (French: L'Aiguille creuse) | image = | caption = | author = [[Maurice Leblanc]] | translator = [[Alexander Teixeira de Mattos]] | cover_artist = | country = France | language = French | genre = [[Crime fiction]] | release_date = 1909 | media_type = Print }} '''''The Hollow Needle''''' is a novel by [[Maurice Leblanc]] featuring the adventures of the [[gentleman thief]], [[Arsène Lupin]]. As with the preceding two volumes of the Arsène Lupin stories, this was first serialized in the French magazine ''[[Je sais tout]]'' from November 1908 to May 1909. The novel was released, with a few modifications, in June 1909.
==Plot summary== [[Image:Cliffs etretat.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The Needle of [[Étretat]]]]
Arsène Lupin is opposed this time by Isidore Beautrelet, a young but gifted amateur detective, who is still in high school but who is poised to give Arsène Lupin a big headache. In the Arsène Lupin universe, the Hollow Needle is the second secret of [[Marie Antoinette]] and [[Alessandro Cagliostro]], the hidden fortune of the kings of France, as revealed to Arsène Lupin by [[Josephine Balsamo]] in the novel ''The Countess of Cagliostro'' (1924). The Mystery of the Hollow Needle hides a secret that the Kings of France have been handing down since the time of [[Julius Caesar]]... and now Arsène Lupin has mastered it. The legendary needle contains the most fabulous treasure ever imagined, a collection of queens' dowries, pearls, rubies, sapphires and diamonds... the fortune of the kings of France.
When Isidore Beautrelet discovers the Château de l'Aiguille in the department of [[Creuse]], he thinks that he has found the solution to the riddle ("l'Aiguille Creuse" being French for "The Hollow Needle", and also the French title of the novel). However, he did not realize that the château was built by [[Louis XIV]], the king of France, to put people off the track of a needle in [[Normandy]], near the town of [[Le Havre]], where Arsène Lupin, known also under the name of Louis Valméras, has hidden himself.
==Sequels== A direct sequel to this novel, featuring Lupin against La Griffe, is the novel ''Le second visage d'Arsène Lupin'' by [[Boileau-Narcejac]] in 1975.
==Principal characters==
* Isidore Beautrelet, the boy detective * Mademoiselle Raymonde * Arsène Lupin * Examining magistrate Filleul * Ganimard, a French police detective * Louis Valméras * The Count of Gesvres * Holmlock Shears
==External links== {{wikisource}} * [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/4017 Project Gutenberg E-text of The Hollow Needle] * {{fr icon}} [http://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/L’Aiguille_creuse The Hollow Needle on Wikisource] * {{librivox book | title=The Hollow Needle | author=Maurice LEBLANC}}
{{Arsène Lupin}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hollow Needle, The}} [[Category:French crime novels]] [[Category:Arsène Lupin novels]] [[Category:1909 French novels]] [[Category:Novels first published in serial form]] [[Category:Works originally published in Je sais tout]]

{{No footnotes|date=March 2014}}
'''Yosemite Sam''' is the [[nickname]] given by [[DXing|DXers]] to a [[number station]] that first surfaced on December 19, 2004. It transmits on several [[shortwave]] frequencies in [[single-sideband modulation|dual side band]]: 3700 kHz, 4300 kHz, 6500 kHz, and 10500 kHz. The nickname is taken from the [[Looney Tunes]] character [[Yosemite Sam]], whose voice is played as part of the unusual transmission.
==The transmission series== The transmission begins on one of the frequencies. Ten seconds later, it is repeated on the next higher frequency, and so on for a total of two minutes. The entire pattern takes precisely two minutes, and always begins seven seconds after the top of an hour.
Each transmission starts with a [[burst transmission|data burst]] lasting 0.8 seconds, followed by the voice of Yosemite Sam exclaiming: ''"Varmint, I'm a-gonna b-b-b-bloooow yah t'smithereenies!"'' The clip is taken from the 1949 cartoon ''[[Bunker Hill Bunny]]''.
The station disappeared on December 23, 2004, but returned during February 2005, on its old frequencies plus additional new frequencies, including those of [[time signal]]s stations [[WWV (radio station)|WWV]] and [[WWVH]]. Reception reports seem to indicate that the transmitter site is likely in the desert near [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], [[United States]]. The Albuquerque location suggests another relation to Looney Tunes: the phrase frequently repeated by [[Bugs Bunny]], "I knew I should have taken that left turn at Albuquerque."{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
Two amateur radio operators claim to have tracked down the source of Yosemite Sam in February 2005 as being located at the ''MATIC Center'' in [[Laguna, New Mexico]], a factory owned by ''Laguna Industries''. As they took pictures of the site they were approached by security guards and left. Three hours later the radio transmission allegedly stopped.<ref>http://www.brogers.dsl.pipex.com/yosemite.html</ref>
==See also== * [[Numbers station]]
==External links== * [http://www.spynumbers.com/YosemiteSam.html "Yosemite Sam" at Spynumbers.com] ''Includes a recording of the station'' * [http://qrg.globaltuners.com/?q=yosemite+sam "Yosemite Sam" at the Global Frequency Database] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20151206060253/http://www.southgatearc.org/news/mar2005/ham_spy.htm "Ham vs Spy (radio)"] (Archived version on archive.org) ''Transmitter site pinpointed''
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = ZAP | logo = ZAP logo.png | type = [[Public company|Public]] | foundation = [[2010 in television|2010]] | location = [[Luanda]], [[Angola]] | industry = [[Telecommunication]] | products = [[Direct broadcast satellite]] | parent = [[NOS (Portuguese media company)|NOS]] | homepage = [http://www.zap.co.ao/ www.ZAP.co.ao]
[http://www.zaptv.co.mz/ www.ZAP.co.mz] | footnotes = }} '''ZAP''' is a digital satellite television provider mainly for [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] speaking countries in sub-Saharan Africa. ZAP launched in Angola in 2010, providing a subscription based TV service covering the sub-Saharan countries to south of Angola. ZAP operates from the Eutelsat W7 satellite, placed over Africa at 36,0 degrees East, broadcasting in DVB-S2 in five {{Ku band}} transponders with MPEG-4 compression and Nagravision encryption.{{Cite web|url=http://www.eutelsat.com/news/compress/en/2010/html/PR%201010%20Zon/PR%201010%20Zon.html|title=EUTELSAT’S W7 SATELLITE WELCOMES ON BOARD ‘ZAP’,|last=Standard|website=www.eutelsat.com|access-date=2017-07-05}} ZAP provides an unprecedented number of Portuguese-language channels for a region where [[Portuguese-speaking African countries]] account for more than 40 million people.{{Cite web|url=http://www.angolaemb.com/informacao/press/press-2010/press-30/press-n30.htm|title=Angola EMB|website=www.angolaemb.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-05}} In order to subscribe to ZAP's television service a subscriber can use either one of the two available decoders. The "HD+" decodes the encrypted signal, provides an Electronic Programming Guide, High Definition image and 5.1 stereo sound. The "HD+DVR" decoder provides the additional functionality of [[Digital Video Recorder]]. ==Channels== ZAP currently offers 150 channels, including several [[HDTV]] channels, featuring TV series, films, music, children’s programmes, news, sports and documentaries. The subscribers may chose one of three tiered channel packages: "Mini" with 35 channels; "Max" with 80 channels; and "Premium" with 100 channels. Additionally ZAP provides several radio channels.{{Cite web|url=http://www.zap.co.ao/#/pacotes/zap-premium|title=ZAP|website=www.zap.co.ao|access-date=2017-07-05}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.zap.co.ao/ ZAP official homepage] *[http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/zap.html Channel and transponder list] {{CATV}} [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Media companies of Angola]] [[Category:Telecommunications companies of Angola]] [[Category:Companies based in Luanda]] [[Category:Companies established in 2010]]
